subject: Re: Newbie Questions: Utility, Reality, and Inevitability
msgSnippet: Thanks for your response. My plan is to learn and use junior for up to a couple of years. I want to become proficient in reading my own writing, and let the
messageBody:
Thanks for your response.

My plan is to learn and use junior for up to a couple of years. I
want to become proficient in reading my own writing, and let the
penmanship nuances which will develop after daily use work themselves
out.

I will make use of the prefx and suffix suggestions in the manual as
well to help speed. During this time, I'll take note of the
connections that appear natural, perhaps incorporate them as well
(gambling that they will comply with the refinement of any rules that
between now and then).

thanks
scrib


--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "Anthony Grahn" <othermale@...>
wrote:
>
> I'm sure you'll find Quickscript(QS) a serviceable shorthand. If not
> as fast as real shorthand, certainly the learning curve is less.
>
> Do you mean to write connectedly (aka Senior) or unconnectedly (aka
> Junior) If the former then there is a great deal I'd like to
discuss.
>
> My primary thrust now and for the last while is to resolve the
> ambiguous and sparse instructions in the Qucikscript Manual (QM) and
> the apparently contradictory examples for connecting letters. You
may
> note if you write connectedly that the rules seem adequate on a
> subjective level but legibility can be a serious issue. Even reading
> ones own writing can be difficult until one builds one's own rules
> (subconsciously at least). So to this end I am even now trying to
> compose a clear and consistent set of such rules and build a
> programmatic reference implementation of them in order to test these
> rules for consistency (in previous posts I've referred to this
loosely
> as a quickscript senior parser) . If your looking into Senior
> quickscript I'd love to hear your observations about the QM and your
> interpretations.
>
> If you're sticking to Junior, I'm sure you'll find it speeds writing
> some and anyway will make software character recognition easier if
> that's where you're headed.
>
>
